message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Paroxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) used to treat depression. Decreased libido is a common adverse effect of SSRIs. Urinary retention and priapism are not commonly associated with SSRIs, and increased suicidality is a potential adverse effect but it is less likely to occur in patients over the age of 24.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the adverse effects of paroxetine, decreased libido is most likely to affect the patient according to his symptoms of depressed mood and loss of pleasure in activities. Increased suicidality is also a possible adverse effect; however, the patient does not have suicidal ideation at the time of presentation. Urinary retention and priapism are not commonly associated with paroxetine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Paroxetine is an SSRI antidepressant, which is known to cause sexual dysfunction including decreased libido, as well as other side effects such as weight gain or loss, nausea, and insomnia. Increased suicidality is a potential adverse effect in children and adolescents, but not typically in adult patients. Urinary retention and priapism are rare side effects of antidepressants, but not typically associated with SSRI use.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) such as paroxetine are known to cause sexual side effects, including decreased libido. The other options are not associated with paroxetine use. Increased suicidality may be a concern in younger patients with depression, but the patient in the scenario does not have suicidal ideation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, only decreased libido is a common adverse effect of paroxetine, which can affect the patient's sexual functioning. Increased suicidality is a rare but serious side effect of antidepressant medications in general, but the patient does not have suicidal ideation at this time. Urinary retention and priapism are more commonly associated with other types of medications or medical conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Paroxetine belongs to a class of drugs called selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) and one of the most common adverse effects is decreased libido, which can worsen the patient’s depressed mood. Increased suicidality is a possible adverse effect of SSRIs, but it is more common in adolescents and young adults. Urinary retention and priapism are more commonly associated with other classes of drugs like anticholinergics and alpha blockers, respectively.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the listed adverse effects of paroxetine, decreased libido is the most common. Urinary retention, increased suicidality, and priapism are all possible but less common adverse effects.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Paroxetine is an SSRI, which can cause sexual dysfunction, such as decreased libido, in some patients. Urinary retention and priapism are rare side effects of SSRIs. However, patients with major depressive disorder are at increased risk of suicidal thoughts, especially when starting antidepressant treatment. Therefore, close monitoring for increased suicidality is necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Among the options, decreased libido is a known adverse effect of paroxetine, and is more common in males. Increased suicidality is a known risk for antidepressants, but it is more common in children and adolescents. Urinary retention and priapism are possible adverse effects of other medications such as anticholinergics and tricyclic antidepressants, but are not commonly associated with paroxetine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Paroxetine is an SSRI that can cause sexual dysfunction, including decreased libido, as a common adverse effect. Increased suicidality is a possible adverse effect when starting an SSRI, but this is usually seen in adolescents and young adults. Urinary retention and priapism are rare adverse effects of SSRI use.
